element_texts.text: Completed

No. 1
1.
Elyria, Mar 29, 1883
Dear Marian:
We all thought that it would be nice to all send you a birthday letter, because you can buy more and better things in Boston than we can here. Isn't it fun that Charlie signed his name? O, how we all laughed while father teazed him! I wish you had been here.
Annie's Junior ex? is Friday. I expect to go. She has a new green silk dress for it. She is going to to wear it out here Thrusday afternoon to call on Mrs Eugene Mussey? with mother.
I am not secratary of Class of '85 now. Anna Starr is. Staf Worthington is Pres and unclear Jewel? Vice Pres. 
I take Botany with the little D's. I was 102, Highest in the class. I was brightest in Zoology? Biology? to where I took that, only Harry was the same as I was, 99. There
Completed

one girl up with me this time, but she had an oral examination.
I had Arithmetic and Botany the same afternoon and I was only 84  in Arith. 82 in Latin.
You have not see Harl's Class Pin have you? It is awful pretty.
Don't I hope I can go down to the lake and see Annie Folger next summer thought! They live in the house just this side of Mr. Boyd's. They said that last summer where we had our great big picnic there, they sat on their woodpile and watched us. They saw some (please excuse that unclear) girls but had no idea who we were. 
O I'd like to go there! There is a cupola on the house and you can see Cleveland from it. The cupola is a real good sized room, and every summer somebody wants to rent it but Mr. Folger won't let any body, cause they want it. They have a creek that goes into the lake and a boat and they can row and bathe and everything. O I wish I lived there!!!!!!!!!!! But we are
Completed

going to Chautauqua aren't we? And prayers? I can go visiting there, Net? and me. And I guess I can go to Cleveland next summer too. Aunt Jennie asked me to on last little vacation but I didn't.
O, I forgot about that letter to Jennie Bullock. I guess the cards were intended for Abbie but father put them in the wrong letter. Jennie's address is 164 East Ave. Pautucket R.I. Never mind about the cards, you can have them if you want to, or bring them home in your trunk.
We are lots beyond that in Caesar - about 37 or 38th Chapter. John Brooks is on the fourth Book I believe, but he only cares about 12 Chap. in a book,
I have two new dresses made two more not made. A light
Completed

very light blue, very fine striped gingham, and a brown (not check nor plaid) calico, made; and a white with black things on it cambric and a white dress not made, and the white not bought. 
The P. in Pete's? signature on the Birthday Card means Poppenhausen?. Pete? Poppenhausen? Metcalf. Isn't that good? I don't know who thought of it. She has no other middle name.
My writing is getting so dreadful. I'd better stop.
It's awful hot.
I've had a dreadful cold all this week. I was out of school Tues. Wed. Thurs. Throat was awfully sore Tues. Wed. Awful cough ever since. It is a lovely day. All the afternoon the setting room tables have been loaded with ink and paper and pens and hands and folks. I'm the only one that is still writing, and now I must stop you see. Wishing you many happy returns of your birthday. I remain, much cramped, Yours, etc? G.E.M.
Completed

April 13th '87
Dear Marion:
We are all tickled to get your letters. Harry and I sit next to each other at table and Jack and Harl on the other side a little way down, with Niva B. between there. Harry and I read our own and each other's at dinner and we saw Harl reading his at dinner too. It is just splendid to be with all the boys again. Harl and Harry and Jack here too. I wish Wayne was here too. We kind of begun to get acquainted last time and will all forget it now.
I very unexpectedly won the debate in L.L.S. by the decision
Completed

of the judges, but I did not do anything at all with it - said nothing at all and was very severely and very justly and moderately criticised at the next meeting. I have an essay two weeks from last Tues Eve.?, which is Apr 26th. Failures to appear at an appointment in Soc. are a terrible thing and I don't know whether or not it would be possible to get any one to exchange with me. And so if the wedding should be Apr 26 what should I do? I enjoy Soc. very much and I know it is or will be very valuable to me, as it is to every one. Much better work is done in Soc. than in Class Rhetoricals, and there is a critique every night which is good, and good discipline both for the critics and the
Completed

others too. There is extempore speaking - subject given after the speaker has reached the platform. There is fifteen minutes of parliamentary drill every night which is good - all is conducted by the strictest conforming to Robert's Rules of Order and the officers are changed once a month so every one has those experiences. The exercises are Critique, Essay, 4 or 5 Ex tempore Speeches, Oration, Essay, Oration, Debate, Parliamentary drill, Business, if I remember rightly. And there thirty or more members so of course you meet nice girls. At home all the energies of the whole family and Mrs. Forage? are spent preparing Anna for the future. It was as much as mother's life was worth? I believe to fix me a
Completed

dress or two to carry me through till the hot weather.
It is too bad you cannot be at the wedding. If I'd been Annie I would wait till July or Aug. or Sept. so you could be there. The idea of Annie getting married and Marion not there. When you will be home or can be, in two or three months. I can't see through it. Probably folks don't think it absolutely necessary but I should. If Mr. R. expects his house to be done for next term he'd better be about it, seems to me. The apple trees still stand, and the grasses and wild flowers are growing, where he says he will have his house by the first of Sept. When is he coming back anyway? 
Jack spent last Sunday in the
Completed

city of Columbus. I wonder if he had a good time.
My studies prosper this term; which they never did before, because of mathematics. I have no mathematics this term and therefore I get my lessons and have some happiness in life. Harl and I had Physics last term. I have Elocution. Eng. Lit. and Greek Lyric Poets all very nice. My favorite kind of studies. Probably they are too easy; but I don't have a bit too much time though. Harl can tell you what he has. 
How long is the Spring Vacation at W.C? I saw Paul Thayer at church once - Jack said it was he, but did not introduce him. That is the only time I
Completed

have seen him. I hope you are having a good time at Millbury. as you are of course unless you are too tired. 
The beautiful weather had been beautiful here too, for over a week. Just grand weather for tennis, and Harl won't fix the court and lend me his (or my) racket an hour a day so it is all wasted for me. How splendid is it is that you can go to the sea shore. I hope you can go soon. and often. Whom do you go with? Can the girls go too? You said you and I would go some time next year.  There is a ball game this P.M. between Sophs. and Fresh.s. but the girls can't go, so I sit in the window and can see the boys pass as I write, and hope - know, of course, that the Sophs will
Completed

win. '89 must not lose the championship. Didn't I tell you that the Sophs. same out in black silk [plugs?]] and rosewood canes, and unclear unclear Yrs. and Soph. girls in little round brown felt class hats with the class colors in cord around them?
Harl and Wayne and every one looks fine in silk hat and rosewood cane. Senior and Junior and Prep and Fresh. all are way back unclear shade. (The Senior Preps have knickerbockers which are splendid and pretty and on all unclear the Sophs had them - Harl and Wayne and a few other are going to)
The Missionary Prayer meeting is today. I wish you could go to it. It is very good.
Margaret Lamberton is going to stay over Sunday with me
Completed

next Sunday. Will not that be nice? She is in Elyria now, at Alex's. Alec had a beautiful baby. The all are very fond and proud of him - he is a boy. Mag makes him pretty clothes. Edith is lonely I guess. I have not been over to see the baby but I want to badly. Well, well, I must be drawing to a close. There are seven girls and nine boys here this term - Frances and Nina? B and Geo.? Wilber and us and lots of others.
But fare thee well for I must leave thee.  With much love
Your sister, Ethel
Completed

Oberlin, Apr, 28. 87
Dear Father:
Should we come home Saturday?
I'm all so mixed I don't know what to do. I haven't come home this term yet, expecting to come this week: thinking that of course we in Oberlin would come home anyway. But last night, I asked Harry, who went last week, how much relatives they were going to have and he said he did not know. And then I happened to think that Julia West, who was over here today, said that the Wellington paper said that Mary had gone to Kansas last week; and I had supposed that unclear was coming
Completed

back this week for the wedding and then Mary going back with him; and I couldn't just believe that Mary had gone. So I asked Jack, and he read us part of a letter from her?, telling how Mary had reached there and they were nicely fixed and all, as I s'pose you know.  And I was so surprised I didn't know what to do, and said, just as nonsense?, "why we have choir meeting Saturday I guess we won't go" - never thinking of such a think as really not going. And Harl and the boys sayed "Why of course we won't go if we don't get a bid," and I thought they were fooling but they weren't, and I was very surprised. They said - "wouldn't you expect we would be invited? and we are children away from home just
Completed

as much as he is. Of course if they want us they would tell us so. But here it is so late if they wanted us to come home we would have had letters telling us to or invitations or "bids" long ago. I said probably they thought we would come any way of course, without invites. But they said we ought to get invites if anybody does. And I said "Hasn't Wayne got one yet?" and Harl said no and I was more surprised. We supposed that if the relatives were invited Wayne would long ago have received a bid as the boys say. And we s'posed if any body got a "bid" we would. And we s'posed that Mary and unclear had got no "bid", and did not know as they were wanted and so gone not to come back. And so the boys say, of course they
Completed

must go if they don't get a "bid". And I think it dreadful. Don't Annie want her own brothers and sisters to her wedding? Don't Annie want her own cousins and her father's own brothers to her wedding? When they live right there? I think it is dreadful. I wonder if Mr. Root is going. I wonder if Net will be allowed to be present. I wonder if Ralph and Mayo will. I wonder if you and mother will. I wonder if any body but Mr. Williams and Annie and Mr. Root will be allowed in the room or in the house. Please tell us we shall come home. Your daughter, Ethel
Completed

"Wi" = Wilder (brother)
Wellesley College
Mar? 7th '88
Dear Mr.
Your very short letter came day before yesterday. Write another immediately! Maybe  the same letter would have looked longer in writing - I wrote to you just a little while go. But as I don't know any more address than Lawrence, Kansas, maybe it was not delivered, and you might get it some time where you are passing the P.O. Mr. Charles Shelton, Secy. for Indian Missions in the Amer. Miss. Assoc. spoke here Saturday P.M. He is fine, it was his best talk I ever heard, on that
Completed

subject or any other most?.  I wish every one could hear it. He has lead lots of years in Dakota at the Rosebud Agency. Mr. North of Middletowe Corner preached Sun. A.M. He married, several years ago, a Miss McCoy 8'79? W.C. daughter of the Secratary of W.C. And they were married here at the College, in the Crel.? Chapel. She had no other home. His wife came with him. You know we have a different minister Every Sunday here. We've had Dr. Abbott, Washington Gladden, Dr. Clark and Dr. Smith Secy's of Amer. Board. Andover Profs. Yale + Harvard and Newton Theo. Sem. Profs. All kinds. It is quite an interesting way. Dr. Strong of Auburndale, Editor of Missionary Harold, talked
Completed

Sun. Eve. about Africa. Auburndale is a village about four miles from here, where the Episcopal Rector is Rev. Henry Metcalf, with a wife, and two or three children. Whom Marion knows and goes to see once in a while, but has not yet this year. We are going when Lent is over. They are very High Church and ritualistic, and M. doesn't know if they ever want to have callers in Lent, she says! They are nice folks she says - We have Lenten services here in the Chapel or this parlor two or three times a month. I have not been to Boston? to see the lights yet. I've been in a good many times, on business to go to the great fair, shopping,
Completed

to go to the Symphony Concert to go to a Recital in Sleeper Hall, New England Cons. of Music, and lastly but not least, to get a tooth pulled - But never had any time to go anywhere yet. We are having the most glorious weather. What kind are you having? Does the spring come earlier there or later? We have had a few days just like early spring, but it is grand winter weather now, but not very cold. But glorious clean air and blue sky and wind and sunshine. How nice it is that Annie can have a piano in her house. But aren't you going to have it in your house before long? How is it that you don't want it? I must study my German which is fine. The German course here is wonderfully good. Unclear unclear unclear. Ethel
Completed

Dear? Wi, I would write a poem in honor of this great day, but no, I am unable to do it the right away! For it should celebrate your virtues and sing your praises many, but mention none of little faults - Indeed you know not any! It should make jokes new and bright. And mention all your funny ways Describe your appearance to the light - Which could indeed be nought but praise! It should tell how we long to see you,
Completed

And hear your voice once more! How sadly we missed both face and voice When we went to the lake as of yore! But words are too feeble and senseless To tell of feelings so deep - We must cast away pen and paper And abandon ourselves to weep! Ethel September 10th, 1890. to Wilder S. Metcalf (Ethel's brother)
Completed
Dear Wi, I love you truly, and I tried hard to make the money go round but it wouldn't and I wish you a very jolly and Merry Christmas and the
Completed

Happiest and best and most prosperous year of life you have yet had. 
Farm. circ. came today (21st)
It is good to hear from you all. Again a very Merry Christmas to you and all!
E.
Completed

57 Bull St Charleston S.C.
June 17th 1891
Dear family
The best family on earth. The most glorious family in the Union. The darlingest family ever seen. Hip Hip Hip Hooray Hurrah Hurrah. For Charles. I feel as if it was a great day for the family. I suppose Harl needs lots of comforting but I suppose I'm not quite thro? needing the prayers yet. I hope Nette may never know how such a school of scholars looks. They are perfectly unearthly for wickedness.
Completed

If I do say it as unclear have kept well all the year till now. (maybe you do not think I have kept still, but I have) But I'll be there by and by - at home and then don't ask me any thing about it for goodness sake. Mother my dress is getting very soiled - the sleeves - nowhere else. But it is a pretty dress and you don't know what heat is, any of you folks. 
Oh won't the Elijah be grand. I hope nobody will have to miss it. Please get me a ticket somebody. Is it necessary to make a more particular request or will you see about it Jack or Az. or Harry? Don't you wish you were perspiring all over and smarting in four places where the gentle mosquito has been, and had had the most beautiful day, outdoors, that ever was made, and
Completed

had had ice cream and peanuts out on the balcony last night - the most beautiful night that ever was seen too, and were going with a crowd of D.D.S and AWA? teachers to sail on Charleston beautiful harbor for three hours or so next Sat. evening? Huh? I do want to see Francis Root and all his aunts and unttys and mother and father and grandparents most mighty bad. I have a right smart spell of homesickness quite steadily all the time. I'm jealous of Harl. No Harl is jealous of me. I guess I'll get home first. It is too too bad Wi has to be off at O.C. Comm. time.
This letter is nothing but these, it is the last year and need from me for a while. Oh "home is the word now"
Completed

which makes me so wild Miss unclear is going Tues PM - If I should go with them I would get home Thurs P.M. Oh sakes alive my goodness gracious me! Ha Ha! This is just fun!"
Ethel
How are all? If anybody catches cold or had a headache telegraph me and I'll come home and see about it.
E
Completed

Did Mr. Ethel Benedict of Wellington, the girls' father, die? Mary wrote he was near it?
230 La Salle Ave Chicago Ill
November 6th 1893
Dear peoples: I am now going to seize some time and try tonite a letter. This is the First Monday I've been at home since I came back. A week ago today was the last Monday meeting in Cent. Music Hall. Bess and I meet every Monday dinner or no dinner because one must hear Mr. McNeill every time we possibly could before he left. He went Wednesday P.M. and the whole house is so lonesome and empty without him. We miss him terribly. He was wonderful at devotions every morning. He is a wonderful preacher and man. Well did I tell you that joy Bess and I had Monday? The meeting is from eleven to one and we had just left and had walked about a unclear
Completed

homeward when we each felt a hand on our shoulders and turned and there was Mr. McNeill - He said "Where are you going? - come with me - Oh for Auld Lang Syne" and just turned us both around and walked us back with him to the Palmer House where he dines when he preaches at noon, and had us dine with him and gave us he dearest beautifulest time of our lives. We will never forget the beautiful Kindness of that man. That evening we girls were all going to serenade him but he went but in the evening and did not get back in time. We sat in 240 parlor in the dark and listened to ghost stories waiting for him but he didn't come. Then Tuesday was the great day and paper folded over I heard him three
Completed

2 times. In the big meeting in Music Hall - then at unclear he went over to Willard Hall in the Homan's? Temple to speak in the "noon Meeting" and we stepped? out and went there too. Then he was the principal speaker in the Evening service in Chic. Av. Church. And after we came home from that he showed us all the great beautiful doll he bought for his wee Kate. A girl who works in Marshall Fields' says it was an Eighty dollar doll but they sold it to him for fifty! Oh but I it was a beauty! And he was so proud of it. He has been just wild to get home all this time, and see his bairns. But Tues night we accomplished the seranade. A great lot of us sang Auld Lang Syne
Completed

and the chant "The Lord bless the and keep thee" in the hall outside his room. Then Wed A.M. he was just beautiful again in devotions for the last time. And lots of girls just wept. And the next morning when Mrs. Capron led devotions again after so long, and talked so beautifully about 23rd Psalm and about him too and prayed for him. I just had to weep myself. Well he is gone. He's out on the Atlantic and I hope he'll get home safe and rested and refreshed. We've missed him awfully and prayed for him everyday, as he wanted us to. Wed. the meeting down in Hooley's Theatre was not so big, but yesterday you should have seen Chic. Av. Church. Both morning and evening. Mr. Moody preached both times and in the evening especially he was simply wonderful. In the
Completed

3
first place it was just wonderful how he packed the church. Maybe come of you have seen him do it. Makes people sit along, Makes ushers bring in chairs. Makes people go to the farthest side and shows them good standing room against the wall. Makes the boys sit on the floor on the edge of platform and makes people crowd up and fill many spot of the choir platform. And of their own accord they sat on the steps to the gallery, till all over, nothing could be seen but faces. Then he preached on of his own wonderful sermons on just "How to be saved" And then he had a big aftermeeting down stairs where scores one after another just rose to say they wanted to be a Christian. He is an absolutely wonderful man. And so
Completed

perfectly humble. He goes to Cincinnatti tomorrow. 
Well have I told you that I've been in the Police Station work since I came back? I go once a week only, to North & Milwaukee Ave Station, Thursday nights. I've only "preached" once. We just have a little short gospel talk and lots of singing. Only half an hour in all. I like it very much. It is from 6.30 to 7, for the men just before they start out on night duty. Don't you think it's a grand thing? My street is about all the work I have besides that. And S.S. class of course which is very interesting just now. I've spent an afternoon each week nearly among them. My cottage meeting has been just fine. We have a nice Swedish girl here now and she goes with us and reads Bi. talks and
Completed

4
prays in Swedish just fine and then Swedish people open up. Six testified last Friday. We had a nice large meeting too - twenty five or so there. A Scotchman named Agnew leads it. Martha Brokaw and I still have the street together.
Today there was a picnic but none of us three went. We had a picnic and a half here tho. Those two are a team - Stell and Bess. They just carry and "terrible" We have a great joy both night and day. I have had to work like fun and yet have done hardly more then one pair of stockings - they (the stockings) were so bad. I've done there of the six or eight things I ought to have done besides wrote this letter. Ought to write about ten. They are having a social down stairs now, the Miss. Volunteers. but I had to write. We rigged up a tic-tac for the window of the parlor where they are, connected with our window, and I go and work it
Completed

now and then. Guess I will now -- I did and broke the string! I'll have to go down and fix it soon as I finish this. There were several things I was going to speak of but can't think of them. O Hurrah for Oberlin! beat Chic. U. 33 to 12! I couldn't go but Roy told me Sunday A.M. A great crowd of Oberlinites were there and did well at shouting. Mr. Stough is in Chic T.S. now, - last might he and Jamie McCord & F. Bridgman were here to church. J. Mc. is in Medical Col & F.B. in C.T.S.
Our house -- 228 is quite an "Emigrants Home" now too. The Swedish girl and a dear German girl live on our floor & Otta? Arta? Wolf an Indian princess on the second floor. There is also a dear little Japanese lady here, wife of a mission native pastor in Tokyo. She came over as a delegate to the WCTU Congress, and her husband mailed her to come here, and study up and if possible, start such a
Completed

5
school in Tokyo. She is a brave little woman.
I was going to write to Marion Harl and Mary - and Wi and Charlie but I see I never can get time, so Mother would you please send them this if you think worth? while and then send it to Jack. Anna can read it when they are home or you can send it to them first. I wish the family letter would come on I want awfully to hear from all. I see very little of Edith she is so busy and so am I, but she is lovely when I do see her. Marion did you see Miss Laigh?? She is a very interesting and lovable girl. Remember me lovingly to her if you see her. Miss Fairbanks who is going there or gone is one of the dearest pillars of this home and will be there. I'd like to send love to her too if she remembers me. I hope I can get you the ballots. Say Harl I did just wish I had some time to go and see Mrs. R.
Completed

and be good to her, and money to travel her over here. I couldn't be nice to her a bit and I wanted to terribly, she was so nice herself so very very nice and she was so good to you. Grace Clarke sent some message or other to you. I've certainly forgotten what. And so did Miss Kerr I believe - didn't you know her a little? The dear beautiful dark eyed Scotch girl with Miss Agnew? Miss Agnew is gone away home. Did I tell you about seeing Mr. & Mrs G.L.S?
The Princeton McDowell who I was first tenor in the quartet with Mrs. Davis of OC. & Ray & Paul is a nice littler man with such a lovely nice little wife and the dearest best baby. Just simply lovely. I just love them both. They are plump and sweet tempered and lovely both of them. They are soon going to move into "the cottage across from So Just. Pl. and keep house. Paul is taking lectures in Rush Medical, mornings, & Ray lives at the Sem. But they are going to sing for
Completed

6
This work all winter with the privelege of eking it out by singing for other people too. So they go Friday to some where to sing five nights for a hundred dollars for some YMCA business. Oh Mary I think of your letter every day and answer it in my mind and maybe I'll have answered it really by the time you see this if you ever do. Thank you very much, Father, for the copy of that letter. It was good for the soul wasn't it? And thank you for telling a little about the Barbers etc. How are the boys and Keyes and Neson? Oh how I want to see them!
Well I must quit and write to unclear and one or two others. It is wicked not to be at that social but I have four holy pairs of stockings yet and a great awful tare in that brown waist which I never can mend. With much love and prayers for love all, Eth
Completed

circle around a finger print
Somebody's finger marks, dirty with Chestnuts Stella bought this P.M. I've washed them eleven times.
Completed

230 La Salle Ave Chicago Mar? 13th
Dear Father and Mother and Harry and boys.
Here Monday had gone again and I did not write. I must resolve to write every Saturday or Monday and do it. It is almost impossible not to fool Mon. away. I practice an hour and a half and that is nearly all the work I did. And besides I fell into an irresistible temptation and fooled Sat. PM away too so I have no time. I will first tell of these last three days, then about the Condientian?. Yesterday Hudson Taylor spoke to us in the Lecture room at 9. As he did not expect to be here today. Then Bess and I ran over to see Mrs McDowell and the baby. In the PM Stella &  I with Bennie Platt, (an old student - a English Northfield boy, who
Completed

had been out singing with evangelists for a long time but is back for a week, used to be in same crowd with R. Atkinson D. Conna? and H Openshaw) and Raplh Atkinson (who is pastor of a U.P. Church in Ravenswood) went to see Emma Sherman Coolidge, who used to be in the B.L. but went home last summer was married in the fall and unclear not far from here. We had a very delightful time. She has a beautiful little flat. She is a very beautiful soprano. Stella Alto, Benj Platt tenors and R. At bass and they had done good old singing. And sat in her beautiful little dining room for chocolate and cake all which she made herself. In the evening there was a debate in the B.L. Men's Dept. on Annexation of Canada and ladies invited. We three, Stella Bess & I planned to go and laugh and carry on and cut up and have a wild time. When we
Completed

2
now mourn and grieve to say we did it, and disgraced our selves. We went way too far and acted just awful and sat in jackcloth and ashes when we got home. We went with B. Platt, R. Atkinson and Scott Lawrence (whom I mentioned once before in connection with skating) to get ice cream after the debate but got home early enough. But we have now made up our minds not to cut up at all except on Mondays and to always be decent even on Monday. The reason I say we had to make up our minds to revel only Mondays was this. Stella came home Friday morning brought in her trunk a great lovely chocolate cake, a lot of cracked nuts, and candied dates. We ate quite a bit in our room, but instead of sensibly eating it all her we had to go and ask three dear
Completed

friends (B. Platt C Alexander & A. Gordon) to go up to the Park and share it with us. And for fear the cake would get old, we had to do it Sat P.M. So off we went and spent Sat PM from 3 till 5:30 on a tear and repented afterwards. I'm not joking about it but confessing and don't intend ever to yield to such nonsense again. 
Hudson Taylor Mrs. T. and Miss Geraldine Gunness? came Sat. night. He preached morning and evening, and at 9. Monday. Miss G? stayed here, led our devotions in the morning oh beautifully. She talked about Rom 13:13. Put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ. (the verse before went to our hearts after all our revelling and then we did it again last night!) She showed ways she thought of in which we should put on the Lord Jesus Christ life. 1. His life of humility & self emptying. 2. " " " faith dependence upon God.
Completed

3
3 His life of compassion of love for sinners all.
4. "     "  " love for whole world, "other sheep, not of this fold." "outermost parts of the Earth"
5. His present life, of resurrection power
6. His life of prayer. absorbed in prayer and this the secret of all.
Then she also preached in morning church, and at 4:30 in the church, and at 7:30 at the overflow meeting in the church lecture room. Then she spoke at the Meth.Training School Mon, AM at the Bapt " " "PM and at Rush Medical College too. She is very lovely the spiritual beauty shines right out. And she talks very beautifully. I talked with a young lady at the close of service in the evening who had decided to be a Christian during the service.
I found two new boys in my S.S. class whom I like very much. My class
Completed

was good Sunday.
I wrote you from Detroit a week ago Thursday PM. That PM I went to the conference on Woman's work and could hardly hear much. Your beautiful Dr. Pauline Root is beautiful indeed but she read a paper and wasn't interesting as she would have been had she talked. Dr. Dowkontt? of the International Medical Missionary Soc. and Institute N.Y. City talked and in his work and words I was intensely interested. He told of the awful need of knowledge of Medicine in nearly all the missionary laws? - the terrible suffering of people and the frightful ignorance of the creatures, even the ones called doctors. And then told of the school he had in N.Y. City where the students get reduced rates at the regular Med. Colleges and board cheaply together, have some Bible study and a good deal of practical medical mission
Completed

4.
work in their Dispensaries, & Missions in NY & Brooklyn. Then that eve. from 5 to 7 the Young Women's C.A. received all the Cady delegates and at that I met his daughter Lillie Dowknott, a very charming & beautiful young girl who is very earnest indeed and active in her father's work, and gave me her father's little book "Murdered Millions" which I'll send you to read, and promised to send me some more things. They have come and here is one, please read it and sent it to Marion or somebody. I was with her till that evening session and there found Mr. Gordon had saved a seat for me which he did every single night from all the unclear crowd and he came home with me every single night too. Which was angel kind of him indeed and relieved me of lots of bother. His father spoke that night I think - no it was Hudson Taylor and Miss Guiness? and they where oh so interesting and impressive about China. Dr. Gordon spoke both Fri. and Sat. evenings and oh he was
Completed

grounds. He and Dr. Pierson, Mr. Taylor & Miss Guinness? gave the very best of the Convention. They gave the great and famous ones, and greater than that, and the root of what really - they are the grandly simple and true ones. Just take and preach the Bible itself. Believe every word of it just as it is, and by believing it they mean take it and live on it. Take every grand immense deep rich promise and believe it as God's own word. And they are the ones who talked about knowing God more than about anything else. I do wish you could get and read the addresses of those four. Maybe I could get them for you. I will try & see about it. Thurs. PM. some of us went down to see Tracy McGregor at his mission. We were there only a few minutes then, but Fri. PM. Mr. Stough and I went and were there a long time, talked with that wonderful beautiful Boy Tracy Macgregor, and saw all of his good
Completed

5.
Helping Hand Mission. I'll have to put off telling about it tho. 
The lady where Arthur Fordlaw? stayed put us up a lovely luncheon for the trip home. He wanted her too and it was all right. And he and I and Amy Chambers and Ray and Paul ate together (Paul was sick tho and ate only limewater & milk but he was able to set up with us). Amy Ch is the older of the two dear lovely Irish girls who are here. Both are Miss. Volunteers Miss Amy almost went on to China with H. Taylor & Miss Guiness?. They wanted to take her. But there was not time to tell her parents, and she that she ought to go under Irish auspices too, for the sake of the people at home. But she will go probably within a year.
Last Thurs. night Miss McDowell went to Police meeting with one and they sang a duet. And after it I went to the next to last Apollo Club concert with Mr. Gordon. It was only male chorus this time and was just wonderful too Oh they did sing beautifully. And Henri Marteau played the violin to make you weep or dance. Oh beautiful
Completed

it was. And unclear Lillian Blauvelt - the Goldsbury's cousin - sang more beautifully than the loveliest bird. Ray showed me a lovely photo of her, he had just received from Rena. She is young and beautiful.  He said "our cousin!" Mr. Torrey? calls himself our cousin too did I ever tell you? He say he has more cousins named Metcalf than anything else. Lots in Canandaigua N.Y. (How do you spell C....?)
The great point is now coming. Mr. Frost who I think had charge of the C.I.M (China Inland Mission) Home in Toronto where all their missionaries go before going to China and who came with T.H.T & Miss Guiness? and is here still - he talked a eleven yesterday (Tuesday) morning. And gave the best, most impressive missionary talk I ever heard, and I've heard many. His two main points were the spiritual condition of the heathen, and the Will of God concerning the Church in regard to it. He had time only for the first of the two,
Completed

6.
but it was oh so deeply impressive - all from the Bible. It was just a summary of what he had found in studying that up for his own conviction. Then this morning he talked at eleven with those who has applied to C.I.M or were very interested in it. And in that he just talked conversationally answering questions about the C.I.M. and their Missionaries. (They have a little over 600 in China now Dr. Taylor said - have been running 27 yrs.) The Mission runs on money the Lord sends, without asking anybody or talking collections in Churches because it is unndenominational and can't rightly ask of churches. But they have never been in debt and never will. If prayer should stop, the C.I.M. would be dissolved - just burst, - for it lives only on prayer from one day to the next and one year to the next. 
And for 27 yrs not a missionary had starved nor anybody else. The Lord gives people the very best, and the trial of
Completed

your faith is more precious than gold", - so he has given that sometimes but if a child of God walks with God God never fails him. And as for me I'd rather go out trusting the Lord himself than trusting the A.B.C.F.M. And so I will try and get you a statement of all their talks and ways? and see if you do not like it. Then Mr. Frost said individually this P.M. all who had applied to C.I.M. and then all who wanted to. I gave my name in, and saw him this PM. He had lived in Elyria - his father built the Water Works!
I had about made up my mind you know to get something of medicine or nursing, and unclear that I had made up my mind to work in the Kindergarten while I was at home if I possibly could get the chance. But he said nursing would be of almost no use there. A knowledge of medicine would - even a little such as one could get
Completed

7.
at a Dispensary. And he said while I am in Toronto I could get that of a Dr. they know at a free Dispensary. Maybe you don't know that every missionary before he goes spends one to six months at their Home in Toronto studying Chinese to see if they can probably learn it, studying their Bibles and learning to know God better and making sure whether he wants them to go. Then the people consult and pray about each one and God always shows them whether to send them out or not. Then I said I was going to, or thinking of staying at home six month or so for cooking, and serving. He said both of those they could teach me in this home. And talked a little about it. Oh I was so delighted about not having to stay here for nursing and everything! Then I said "but I ought to spend some months at home with my people before going". He said yes but that would be better after the time at Toronto.
Completed

He said stay here till next Fall as Mrs. Capron said. Then come to Toronto a few months, then come home all under appointment and stay till money was send in- by the Lord some way- for me to go. And then being under appointment people would be more interested and learn about the mission and maybe want to give to it. And I would like ot tell people about the China Inland Mission. They don't know anything about it there at home. It is like a big family. Now please tell me what you think! I wish I could send you some good information about C.I.M. and I will soon as I get some. Josephine Desmond a dear little girl here is going in the fall - has her papers now making them up. Lots of BI's are offering. It is grand. It makes me happy to see a way to go. I wish only that 43 unclear Ave. and the whole family could be trans-
Completed

8
ported there too! Then nothing would send the poor heart of me. God Bless you all very much. Where are you reading mornings now? S.S. lessons? Please write me soon. And if you do not object I will write applying to the China Inland Mission. That's what Mr. Frost said to do. Bess has decided for China In. Miss. too and will talk with Mr. Frost today. We expect to go, together and Stella had decided at last to be a For. Miss too and she is going to talk with him today and find out about China Inland Miss. and if she takes to it as Bess and I do maybe the three will go together after all. Oh wouldn't it be lovely and good of the Lord to let us three go together! Then I'll be wanting and looking for Teddy and unclear over there, and maybe all six of you boys will come. And maybe Harry too. You all want to come to B.I. first.
God bless you all good bye. Write soon Eth.
Completed

Dear Marion
We have agreed to refer this letter of Ethel's you to assess for advice. We do not know any thing about "China Inland Mission", Mr. Frost, "Toronto Preparations". or Prayers as a sole basis for Missionary Operations. Please write to Ethel and write to us what you think about it.
All well as usual here. Uninterrupted fine weather here this month. except that Thursday morning at 5 oclock was a very violent thunder & lightening shower with snow or sleet instead of rains. but turning warm after it, and no trace of it left at night except some this mud in the streets.
Sincerely Father
Ethel China Inland Mission writing fr. Chicago.
Completed

230 La Salle Avenue Chicago Ill.
Dear Father and Mother and brothers and sister.
Work begun Monday morn. The walk to the kindergarten is twice as long or more than I imagined, yet a comfortable walk. Besides the half dozen blocks north of here to Elm Street, it is eight or ten west, beyond Larabee - nearly to the River. It is in one of the worst regions of the city. There were twenty children Monday and thirty for today (Tuesday). The head-director is Miss Lily Wadsworth. She gives us a talk (the three assistants) after the room is righted, so we all have to bring luncheon. Then I walk to the College - two miles- the rest take a car but it's only a goodly walk and I get there before they do, tho' I stop at 230 and get my mail. Wasn't I glad of Father's and Mother's letters this afternoon! Lectures at the College are from 2.30 to 4.30. Then I walk up home in half and hour or forty minutes. About four miles walk a day out to just be good for me. But I will be only four days of the week. I've got to buy some books and some materials before next Tuesday. Have no
Completed

idea how much they will cost. There is only one store in the city where they keep them so I can't get cheated. Will buy them tomorrow maybe.
Yesterday Bess and Marie and all their table went up to the Park to eat a watermelon Fred ordered for Bess, and some of the gentlemen went with them, and they went out to Lake Michigan and Marie hurt her knee on the break water in some way and had to go to the doctor on the second floor this morning after first Lectures. We hope it won't be serious. It is so awfully black and blue outside that it doesn't seem as if it could be very inside! Have you see Fred Brooks? Must go to bed. Will write some more when get time. Jennie Davies was up here a while after supper talking of street people. I know lots of these as she has my street I'm glad to say. She is good. She said give you her love mother and she will write you some time. I took supper with Mrs. Harper and Charlie in the other dining room tonight. Charlie goes to Bryant and Stratton Business Coll. now, down town - goes on? his wheel everyday and takes luncheon. His Coll is on same street my Coll is I guess.
I tho't I wrote you Sunday but I guess not. So will say that Sat. AM I went out to Ravenswood for five? cents -  Anna and her mother welcomed
Completed

2
me just beautifully. Anna had to come into the city on a 10:37 train, and I had to come to the Kn? Coll sometimes so I came in with her and she insisted on paying my fare- seven cents. Then she took me to lunch with her and a friend of hers at Marshall Fields! Then I went up and registered at the Coll. and was assigned to go Elm Street. Then came home and had just about finished my washing when Alfred Edwards was announced to me and I skipped to change my gown and by and by we went up and called upon Grace Clark for five minutes. Then we went down to the Lake and walked a mile or so to the Park and rode back as A had to catch a train home. Ironed after prayer meeting. I must tell you that Mrs. Olson is such a grateful woman she insisted on washing my blankets for nothing. I gave the boys some of my cookies and have one book left of those A. Pitkin bought me, which I will
Completed

give them. By the way those cookies I bought are doing well. I eat one every morning about six to steady me till breakfast time. (I've been about asleep by nine ever night lately and up before six) They aren't all gone yet guess I'll have to buy more when they are for my constitution needs them unless it would cost less to send a lot by express. I should almost think it would. I bought tonight (Wed) two books we have to have. Froebel? Mother? Play," and Miss Harrison's Study of Child Nature. The former $1.50 latter $1.00. Hon to have besides Reminiscences of Froebel 1.50 and Child Nurture Papers or some such name $2.80. Had to get also 46 cents worth of materials. I see a lot of work and a great lot of study before me, all very enjoyable if I can do it well. Have to write abstracts of all the Lectures. One of Miss Harrison's lecture today is kind of tough. The Delsarte is going to be heaps of fun. Must go to work. Have doorbell tonight to have to set up till plumb ten. Much love, Eth
Completed

230 La Salle Avenue Chicago
April 9th 1894
Dear Mother, 
You know that tennis net Harl and I had in Oberlin that is now in the boys' closet downstairs there - north room? I think it is there up on the shelf in the corner or somewhere. Would it cost much to send it by mail? It isn't heavy surely.  We want it very much to decorate the room with, and it's no use there, is it? I would be very very grateful if you could sent it along.
One of our Policemen died last Monday a week ago. The Sargent at our station died very suddenly sitting in a chair there in the office at the Station about 2.30 PM. Went to sleep, and they found he was dead. Heart failure. Of course it was a great
Completed

shock to them all and a great warning and opportunity for a solemn lesson for us to give them. We went to his funeral Wed. P.M. Our meeting there was Thurs and it was my turn to preach. Stella was sick and couldn't go. Amy Chambers (from Ireland, going to China C.I.M) went with me. It was a solemn meeting and solemn time. We had a little talk with the Desk Sargent afterwards. And another officer told us that another officer's little girl had died Saturday and we forced out where he lived and we went to see his wife. And she is a very beautiful little woman and very lonely without her baby. She first and only baby, only five month's old. She is Danish. Her father and mother came in while we where there - a nice fat Danish couple, speak no English. 
Friday night we had a good meeting at the home, a nice Christian Norwegian
Completed

2
whose wife does not speak or understand English.
A man has died on my street who is going to bring some people to Christ by his death. A brother of two drinking families I have told you about. One husband and wife were lead to Christ about two weeks ago by Mr. Gordon on a Saturday night. I do think he can bring the other brother (a reckless young drunkard who wife has been praying for him all winter) by means of the death of this brother. This one who died used to be just as tough as the other but died trusting in Christ and happy, and talked to his brother and all of them in a way I hope they'll not forget. A. Gordon is going to see this one on my street tomorrow night. It is prayer that does these things and I must be praying a lot of the time. And I must
Completed

tell you another thing that prayer has done. Have I told you of a drinking and swearing husband and wife (Norwegians) that I began to visit early in the winter? And about Jan 1st he was arrested and taken to the Bridewell Jail - crazy drink and in a fight with a carving knife? Well I began to go to his wife all the time and talked and read and prayed with her and she has become a Christian I'm sure and we have prayed all winter that her husband would be converted there in the jail that God would go to him there and that he'd come out a different man. And today I went there and he was home, came Saturday - a Christian man! He used to be a Christian years ago - told me all about how he fell last summer and how awfully low he went thro no work, bad company
Completed

3.
and drink. And how he prayed in his cell at Bridewell and how he trusted the Lord to keep him from falling. And how they weren't going to have bad company or liquor come into the house. How he had tho't of his poor wife while in the jail and prayed the Lord to send somebody and get him out of jail - he was in for a term till Sept 10th. And their landlord went out there last week on election day and got him out. And it was only the Lord who took care of his wife and kept the roof over her head and food enough for her, and coal. Well it is all wonderful. I am so goodfornothing and so wicked I can only thank God for letting me help a little bit in such things - it is a wonderful privilege. 
Lona Van and her brother went home
Completed

last week to their sister's wedding! Came back today and brought a big cake which their sister made so Arthur Gordon ordered ice cream and invited Stell and me and Mr. Van invited Lona and Cora McCandlish (an exceedingly pretty first who is going to India) over to supper tonight. We had the jolliest time. And Arthur Gordon gave Stell three pictures of his room at Harvard, to decorate our room with, and I actually stole one of Mr. Hillton's Boys Brigade flags and it looks fine up in our window. I'm afraid I'll have to give it back tho. They sent some cake and ice cream over to Bess - and she's so proud she don't like it. Please do send the tennis net for we need it much. We are going to see Hull House next Sat. When I'll have some more to write about. Mrs. Capron thinks
Completed

4.
that prayers are splendid investments to make if you want to make some in my people I'd be glad. This young Nelson that A.G. is going to see tomorrow night pray for him and his wife and his two little boys. It will be hard for them to grow as a Christian family. And the Johnson family- Mrs J. is Mr. Nelson's sister - they have two tittle children tho? Geo & Mamie and you see it is hard for such poor people in these poor streets of chicago. And these two Ekeroth's - the one just out of jail - he must get work or it will be terrible for him. And two young Swedes who room there and are Christians - both out of work and it's awfully hard to stand, I know. I mean to stand firm as a Christian without money or work. Well goodbye. How about Kinder
Completed

garten tho? David Conn my dear good boy friend says he would stay here and go right on and trust the Lord for the money for board when it was needed. He would get it too. The Lord is so good to those who trust him. He advised me that way. Don't think I tell everybody my circumstances. There are two or three boys who are as good friends as Stell and Bess almost, and David is one. I must go to work and to bed. May God bless and keep you all and all the family. I'm crazy to hear from you for Tuesday is gone and no letter came. Oh how I do want to see you all and hug you especially my darling Keyes and Nelson! I think of them! Ralph won't you go to China with me? Won't you? 
Eth
Completed

Jan. 95. about unclear
My very darling Father, and dear sisters and brothers whoever see this. 
The Mr. Hall you know a little of Father dear, is planning to go to see you. I think next week some day. I guess he writes you today if he did not last night. He probably will be there only an hour or so - go some night and see you in the morning and come right back. I don't know what in particular to say only that if you are satisfied with him why then I will be. I do hope you will be, tho. He's a good man. But there's a horrible lot of things to think about and arrange and don't you worry. The Lord our God will work them out for us. Have no time to make unclear
Completed

Oceanville Maine
August 23, 1895.
Dear Annie:
I am afraid I didn't thank you that Monday for the excellent handkerchiefs I was so very very glad to receive from you. You don't know how grateful I was - they are just exactly what I longed for even to the cut? and quality, only I'm afraid you broke up your purse to get so many such good ones - and that bothers me a bit. Truly it was good and thoughtful of you. Marion gave me some fine linen ones too like yours. And Lizzie Delbett and Mary each gave me a fine linen embroidered one, so
Completed

I feel quite happy.
There are many other things making me happy too - In fact the whole of each day is full of such. We have indeed struck the very place of all the country where we would enjoy life most, I believe - It is so very quiet and mild and far away, and so beautiful, and so many jolly things to do. We have a good time all the time - Today it is raining hard and I have darned all the stockings and socks. We have not been sailing or rowing for two or three days on account of weather and a slight spell of ill health on my part, but we had just as
Completed

good a time -
Quite a number of Oberlin and Wellesley people have boarded here in other years. What do you hear from your wandering boy? How are you and Francis getting on? It almost makes med homesick to think of you - we had such a comfortable time 'keeping you company." I hope it is all good news from England, and I hope Francis is a good boy and thoughtful, and especially I hope you are in good health, happy and at peace. With love and prayers
Are you in Elyria? Ethel
Completed

1657 Paliver Street
Summerdale
Chicago Ill.
Dear Father:
You and Eli and [[Keyes}] and Nelson are very very good to me - Thank you so much for your letters. I'll answer the boys' as soon as I can. We are right in the rush here now - It was no rush at all till we came but the church needs so much that we resolved to put all the life and energy we can into it. Harold has more than he can do already - Every suggestion he makes is eagerly seized and acted
Completed

upon and (because we know every thing he thinks of and every earnest spirit in the people is an answer to prayer) he has to pitch in where they ask him to, and help carry out things. We wish we were in our house already - We are planning to have returned missionaries out from the Institute as often as we can arrange meetings for them, and try to awaken an interest in missions. We hope to keep the missionaries at our house. It is rather funny - my determination to have company all the time. But I'll have Mary Gardner and people who can cook
Completed

2
and I'll get them to teach me. Mary was out here with us yesterday to lunch. She enjoyed the beautiful clear air - and hemmed a napkin for me. She was crazy to hear Paderewski and Harold wanted me to hear him (he has been at their house in London) and in spite of the expense we went down to his recital in the afternoon. It gave Mary G. a lot of pleasure anyway, besides ourselves - and we will economize in other ways! Ella Maddock of Elyria is at the B.I. - we will have her out at our house.And any other B.I. people -
Completed

Doesn't it seem strange to see letters from Miss Jennie Davies already in the C.I.M. paper? Mary tells me that Bessie is not going until August - I'm afraid she's very disappointed but for her Mother it is nice. Why is it she is kept back? She and we may go together after all, and how lovely that would be!
Yesterday they put in the floors of two rooms and a half, and a good deal of the other woodwork upstairs. The stairway has come today, which delights me above all things. Did I tell you we have bought the
Completed

dining room china and bedroom crockery? The latter we got very very cheap. We miss Will and May Hilton horribly out here. Harold will try to see them in town today but we have not seen them for several days, and I can't for one or two more. I have a children's meeting tomorrow afternoon - part of this evangelistic event. This writing is very very bad I know. Will try not to hurry so, next time. Have to go out now with some of these lodgers.
I do hope your thumb is well now Father dear, and your cough too.
Completed

How is Nette in health? I wish I could be at home a while every day, I would try to help in the mending - I'd really try to do something Nette! Thank the boys again for writing. I'll answer soon. Wish Ike and Mayo would write now!
May God bless you all.
With much love,
Ethel
What is the baby girl's name?
Completed

Chicago, Jan. '96
708 Winona Street
Summerdale
Chicago 
February 6. 1896.
Dear Father:
I am awfully sorry again - one letter I have failed entirely to write - You will know it is because of so much to do - being so engrossed in moving into and settling in the new cottage. We came Thursday last week. That day we went back to the unclear to dinner, but ever since we have lived here. The first
Completed

morning the stove seemed impossible to start and we made tea with the little spirit lamp and kettle. This morning was the first time it did not give Harold no end of trouble and keep us waiting till towards noon for breakfast. but he has found the ways of the creature now and we think it will be a good range. It burns hard coal. I wish you could all come in now and see the cute little house - it is so very convenient and easy. The main floor is pretty well in order now, and all the up stairs except the sewing room, which is chaotic. The basement is not in order
Completed

yet, waiting for a cupboard which a dilatory man is pretending to make. For the same reason the pantry is not arranged yet. But the house is very comfortable and pretty - and I wish you could see it. You will wonder how I get on with the cooking. The first day or two Harold did it. Then I did as he taught me, and for two days now I can say I have "got dinner." and it seemed all right and it was fun too. Will and May were here Monday and Tuesday one night and we had jolly
Completed

times. Monday night when they were here was the first time we had dinner regularly in the dining room - it was exciting for me! May helped me get dinner - or rather she did it and I poked around. Now we are pretty well settled Harold will soon take up his work again, with a good deal more here in the Summerdale church. He is going to begin having charge of the Sunday School next Sunday and has many plans to bring it into better shape and make it more useful.
I've had letters from Marian and Karl this week, which were good. It was good to get one from you Father, the first
Completed

morning we were here. I wonder if Marian will be quite well when she comes home? When is she coming? I will write Nette as soon as I can - but I hope - we hope she can come out here before very long. Karl sent me some of those very very beautiful photographs of Elyria views, which we both enjoy exceedingly. It is awfully good of him isn't it?
Anne Pitkin was down here a week ago today and told us of the Oberlin Alumni Banquet tomorrow night, and the plates much cheaper than usual. And we really
Completed

plan to go. won't that be joyful!
Harold is fixing the furnace for the night, and now we will go to bed. I hope you are well Father, and that no one is sick in the household. We hope for another letter very soon. We are so glad to get them.
With much love and prayers,
Ethel
P.S. Friday am. The cupboard came and was set up this morning and I'm going to try and get the cans and pots and pans arranged today. I hope you are having some of this glorious weather too.
E.
Completed

708 Winona Street
Summerdale Chicago
February 22, 1896
Dear Father and family:
I wish you could come and see what a good time we have in our cosy little house. It is rather hard for Harold I fear, he does to much of the work which I ought to do. But he is a beautiful cook and as I've told you before - And he washes the floor also and keeps us clean. People could think I was
Completed

a very bad housekeeper (as I am) if he was not such a good one. As it is they seem to get the idea that I know how, when it is all Harold. We greatly liked to hear Grace Kerr, poor lonely stranger in a strange land, to spend Sunday with us. She seemed to enjoy her herself wonderfully but wrote afterwards that it made her very homesick for Scotland. Mary Gardner came out Monday for a few hours. She wants to see Nette here - won't it be jolly, Nette, to have her out when
Completed

3
you are here? When can you come? You will know by Monday night how much good the Sanitarium has done Marian, won't you?  I suppose you are all wild to see her again. I do hope she is feeling immensely better, and that you will write us. Father dear we did miss your letter very much this week - where was it? We do hope you are well and that you will write us tomorrow.  My worst difficulty is in
Completed

4
keeping the accounts I believe -  you know I always was weak there. They have come out pretty straight tonight at last however.
We had a funny time yesterday - I especially - Will and Ida Johnson and little Ralph and Brownie were coming Thursday to dinner, but it was to bitterly cold what for the children's sake the put it off till Friday - We got her note Friday morning saying they were coming, but Harold had made
Completed

5
arrangements to go with Mr. Wylie to a meeting about twelve or fourteen miles away - down on the South Side - and he could not put it off. They had to leave at 5.16. Ida and the little boys came early in the P.M. and Harold met them at the train but he had to go before Will's train came at 5.30. So Will had to inquire his way to the house. His own little boys gave him a tremedously jolly welcome (they are very wildly fond of him - he's a
Completed

6
good father). Ida had said he often cooked the steak after he got home when they were keeping house (they are boarding now) so I asked him to do it this time and he did - I knew he would cook it to suit himself, while I did not know how they did like it.  We always do these with Worchestershire Sauce. So he and Ida both got dinner all in the kitchen together and we all had a jolly time. They took an early train after dinner on account of the children.  I had another
Completed

7.
caller during the evening, and with her and doing the dishes got through the evening very well. I was really glad on the whole that they did not come Thursday for I had a talk to give a the Women's Foreign Missionary Meeting in the church, which I forgot all about of course when Ida first proposed to come Thursday. It was not that coldest day, and it was a very small meeting but it was very good though. Harold is on Sunday School. (this letter had been written in patches). I expect he will bring some teacher home with him.
Completed

8
We have heard from as many as a dozen families how much the children enjoyed the quiet S.S. last week. It is pleasant to know that they appreciate the difference in that one respect. We hope for many more founts? of improvement. Harold is working hard over it. Our house is to pleasant -  every room is beautiful, it seems to us. We are so glad Nette is Coming and will see it. We hope she will enjoy it. The Kitchen is such a bright and cosy room. Every room is very light and bright, except perhaps the tiney bedroom. The air is simply
Completed

9.
glorious. We are grateful to God every hour.
We hope to hear from you on Tuesday, and from Marian soon. We hope she will surprise you by her health. I wish we could see you all now. How are Ky and Elelson? and Mayo and Eli and Ikie?? We want to know of each of you.
I believe my letter will generously go on Mondays after this and I will try hard to be regular.
It is after church now - or during church rather, and
Completed

10. 
Harold is there. He brought home three of the S.S. workers - the two Richter girls, theaches, and thier brother, the Secretary. They are as the name tells, German. Nearly every one here is English - the others German or Swedish.  These girls both work all day during the week - on at typewriting etc - and the boy is a plumber but works at what he can get.  They are about as bright and intelligent as any one there, and are very much interested in the work - S.S unclear C.E etc.  We all made some plans and talked over actions, for the S.S. They stayed to dinner - or lunch rather and I've just got the dishes done.
Completed

11.
It is lovely to have a home for a headquarters for work. Harold's ridiculous college has closed lectures until next September. He's going to put in the time studying of course. Aren't thse S.S. lessons beautiful nowdays - but you had the Blaxcolie? lessons. I don't know what they are. Again I will end up this lettr with a great deal love.
Ethel.
Completed

Chicago - '96
708 Winona Street
Summerdale
March 15, 1896
Dear Father and Marion and Nette.
Thank you for the letters - we were so glad to get them. I've been intending to write all the week but didn't get time.  I hope Marion's headaches really cease as she wears her glasses. It is something to be awfully thankful for isn't it. I can't find the letters tonight but several questions were asked about the Hiltons. They are our guests - May ought not do any work but she gets so tired of sitting that she always
Completed

dries the dishes for me once or twice a week. We have only two meals regularly, breakfast and dinner. Everybody eats what they want for luncheon. Mary cooks up something for herself, whatever she craves, and washes her own few dishes after it.  Or if we have our luncheons together I wash and she wipes. Will is never home during the day except par of Mondays and once in a while another few hours.  He almost always has to be off to the city before our breakfast, and never gets back till eleven or so.  Some mornings he makes
Completed

2.
himself some tea with the spirit lamp and has a breakfast of bread and butter before going. We always count on having him at dinner on Mondays, and sometimes Fridays.  Last Friday we were all at home for luncheon and Harold and I heaped a plate with piles of cold roast beef sandwiches and we all ate of it joyously. I roast beef about once a week and it makes the favorite lunch of Harold the whole of the week.  We had a good Irish stew once this week, and lovely soup the next day. I love cooking, though I
Completed

don't do very much. I've made gingerbread and johnny bread but never quite a success.  I'm planning to bake white bread tomorrow or Tuesday.  We get splendid homemade white bread now from our grocery.  Some woman makes it. Oh thank you, Father, for telling me about that misspelled word.  It is ridiculous and I hope not to do it any more. I'm glad you saw the cute little pictures of Mayne's baby - Thank you Father dear and Marian for asking us to come home. Harold says Wayne
Completed

Private
3
we all will in the fall. Father we are thinking we will bring you a grandchild next time we come! Won't it be great - Please don't tell anybody. Harold has rather a hard time Sunday nights - There is hard crowd of boys who make noise and disturbance in and around the church at every service, especially all Sunday night.  Harold is the only one who can do anything with them.  They are all right always if he is near - or even if Mr. Wylie says he iwll report them to Mr. Hall! Harold has no trouble at all, only it is
Completed

disagreeable.  And he has to be there to much of the time Sundays. May is gone to church with him tonight. He went to over at quarters to seven to look after these boys (who disturb the C.E. meetings awfully in he doesn't) and come back for May at church time. She is astonishingly better. Has felt wonderfully well today. One of the young men in a S.S class of the Church where Will plays (this is a class of forty young men, who all compose a Glee Club which Will trains) sent Mary a great basket of all kinds of fruits last night, and
Completed

4
they seem to have done her great good. We have apples on hand all the time but other things are almost too expensive.  Apples are bad enough in that respect. There was a basket of strwberries in the bottom of the basket and how delicious they looked, and tasted! We had them for dinner tonight. She is so much better that they have been looking for a flat out in this region, and seem to have almost decided upone one. We think they are planning to take it for the first of April but we do not know.  How are Keyes? and Nelson?
Completed

How are Ike and Eli and Mayo? What is the subject of the Commencement oration - has he already begun on it? What is Harry doing?
What do you hear from Charles and Mary and Wilder?  How is the baby in Oberlin and what is her name?
How is my Father now days?  We both speak often of having you visit us together, and hope you will next summer.  I believe you would like it for a little while. We hope you all are well and in comfort and want to hear from you
Much much love. Ethel
Completed

Ethel, Chicago, '96
708 Winona Street
Summerdale
March 24, 1896
Dear Father, and sisters and brothers.
I'm very sorry not to have written Sunday May was very ill all day, alarmingly morn to towards night. Harold had to go down town to se the murse, and telephone the doctor for advice.  Will of course is away all Sunday - goes off before any one is up. (He is at Grace? Church morning afternoon and evening. I was going to write but in the trouble and all I forgot it.
Completed

2
She was better Monday but needed much attention and Will was at home all day too. And every person in the house needed each meal at a different time from that when any other person had it. Mary always needs to eat often, but when she is about the house she cooks up little things for herself between breakfast and dinner. Harold stayed in all day and worked like a good one, but I was tired at night and he would not have me get up till nearly noon this morning. He got a breakfast for Marnie, one for himself and Will, and another for me and washed all the dishes. This evening
Completed

he wiped all the dishes and cleaned the knives, after dinner before going to the men's Bible study meeting in the church. I'm sorry my letters are not very regular father. But perhaps a married woman has more excuse, don't you think so? I think the Hiltons will be with us till May, and then we will look for Nette. We look forward to having her with great pleasure. We do hope she will enjoy it. I forgot to say that Mary is better today, has been about down stairs. Her doctor came out yesterday from the city and was quite encouraged. He said to Will that he was
Completed

4
fortunate in having found such a good place to stay in, which pleased us very much. This is a very remarkably healthy place. These postals about the prayer meeting Harold got up and had printed himself for Mr. Wylie. This is the second week they have used them. These other things are some of the things he has got up. I thought Marion might be interested. They explain themselves. The postals addressed to himself are for the J.S. teachers - he gave each teacher some of them. He has a splendid system of keeping record of attendance of children by cards and punching.
Completed

5
These books are from the the Bible Institute Colportage? work - he has just begun that - only one day in the church and sold only one book. It is for the two purposes of getting the people to have these helpful books, and of helping on the work of finishing the church by the profits. They built this church - mostly by the work of the members by the day (they are all working people) five years ago and dedicated it free of debt. They are still free from debt because the Pastor always gives them back (before even they give it to him) the part of his salary they ought to pay, and lives on the little the City Missionary Society
Completed

6
pays him. But only the basement has even been finished, and they are being waked? up to finish it. They are all poor people but they don't give and they ought to, and any way God will help them make the money and it will do them good. This letter though late is pretty long and I must go to bed. I never have answered Marion's last letter nor thanked her for the beautiful traets? in it. It was and is a great pleasure to read them - they are splendid to give away aren't they? How are all the kids and all of you? Eth
Completed

Thank you immensely Eli and thank you exceedingly Harry for your notes - it does me good to see your two handwritings and we do beg you (and Mayo and Ike and Keyes and Nelson and Nette) to do it often and again. I've written all I can think of in the letter to all and must bid you a splended good night and a very good day to follow it. Yours with hearty love Ethel. Harold is away or I'd try to get him to add a mark of some kind.
Completed

708 Winona Street
Summerdale
Unclear April 5, 1896.
Dear Father and Marion + all:
Thank you for your good letters, you and Marion and Eli. Eli's was almost alarming though he said every one was well with the exceptions mentioned, namely father, Marion, Nette, Harry, Mayo, himself, Ike
Completed

Keyes and Nelson. I wish you would explain Keyes's and Nelson's sicknesses - Saint Vitus' dance and "crying" I do hope they were only temporary and isolated attacks. Mary is better again. The weather is simply lovely, and she has taken little walks the last two days. Today - Sunday again, she is not quite so spry, but has been down stairs and very cheerful -
Completed

nothing like the last two Sundays. Will has a great day of work at his church today. See his programs - He gives nearly as much and altogether as fine music every Sunday. He is immence. The day is rather unusual in our little Church too. The chalk talk this afternoon is not over yet. We hope it will do much good.
Completed

We speak almost daily of Nette's coming. If the Hilton's go the first way we want Nette to come soon after. We both, to tell the truth, are a little tired, especially I, and we have a scheme to stay abed about a week after they are away, and admit only the milkman and grocer. I don't know but we will abandon that plan though - I feel better than a few days
Completed

ago. Of course the days Marnie was worst I got tired. By the way it is funny you think they are boarders. They are our great friends. We don't feel quite big enough about or housekeeping and cooking to take boarders yet. Sometimes they have to rough it, especially Will. He often gets his own breakfast. Though all this last week Harold has got everybody's.
Completed

I had a good letter from Annie yesterday. I can't realize? the baby girl is three months old. Have you all seen her? How does she look - like Francis? I long to see them and all of you. How are Keyes and Nelson anyway? And how is everybody? How do you all spend Sunday afternoon now? I think of the woodpile and the cellar door and Sunday School
Completed

books and hickory nuts on these spring Sundays. Mrs. Kirk the nurse just stepped in on her way from the church and she says the meeting was very very good. She seems to have got good and I'm glad it was a success. Please tell how Marion is whether quite well of headaches and everything bad. How are Nette's eyes? How are you each? That Hilton at the head of
Completed

Will's Sunday Air program is a mistake. He often plays his a own music but he left that blank that time and the printer foolishly put that. P.S. Harold brought his evangelist Miller home to Tea and we had a nice time. They had a good meeting. There were fifty six of these cards signed. Many were S.S. children and Harold + Mr. Wylie are going to have a meeting with them this week. Goodnight. Please write. With much love, Ethel.
Completed

708 Winona Street
Summerdale
Chicago.
Dear Father and family. 
It is Sunday night and Harold is gone to church. It has been a lovely day like all of late, and an easy one. He'll Come home for the
Completed

afternoon, May has felt well all day, and every day lately; Harold gets breakfast almost alone and every one gets his own luncheon if he wants any. I wash dishes and May wipes generally. This morning Will had to go early, as usual and May got up early
Completed

too, and they had breakfast together, and then Harold and I got up and had ours. May always does at least half of getting dinner too, now she is so well. We have invested in a cheap but very good oil stove with three burners, which is a great
Completed

institution for us It will boil a quart of water in five minutes. It saves Harold a good hour every morning. He has begun fixing up the yard.  Has planted morning glory seeds all around the verandah, and dug up sods on the prairie around, for the front yard. That will take a
Completed

lot more work though. How deep do you put morning glory seeds? He bought mignonette and sweet pea seeds too, but how expensive they are if you buy any quantity! I wish we were there at home - you have lots of kinds of seeds haven't you? But I suppose no more of them than the garden
Completed

needs though. Have you planted things yet? I hope the garden will be fine this year as usual. Do the kids all work like good fellows? What is Harry doing now days? Will some one please answer that question? Please! How are Nette's eyes,
Completed

and Marion's headaches? Are there any other troubles? How are you all? Are you well Father? What is the baby's name? Please be writing to us tonight! 
With much love and many prayers for you all from Harold and me
April 19, 1896
Completed

Rev Dr. Daniel, - Elyria Aug. 20 1894
Dear brother
In reply to your inquiries about Miss. G. Ethel Metcalf I have this to say:
1. She is a daughter of one of our best + most practical Christian families. At an Early age she became an open decided Christian, + has since made a clear steady progress in the Xtn life.
2. She has a bright active mind, ever learning + ever gaining new stores of knowledge. She possesses a ready sound practical judgement - "a sanctified common sense" - not at all cranky or crotchety.
3. She is accustomed to Xtn work - has a genuine love for it - is quite at home in it - Eminently gentle + judicious.
I know of no young lady whom I could so unreservedly recommend as fitted to be a true, faithful, successful missionary at home or abroad. - possessing in marked? measure the proposed "qualification for missionaries + assistant missionaries."
Very truly yours,
Edwin E. Williams
